p: Higher parental education is generally associated higher vaccine uptake in US children, [ 41– 43] though the returns of higher education may differ by race/ethnicity, particularly with regards to health behavior. [ 70] Intersectionality is a fundamental concept not just as it pertains to social disadvantage but also as it pertains to health, [ 32– 35] yet has unfortunately been largely neglected in the health literature. [ 31] Public health and health policy researchers have placed increasing recognition on the notion that health equity can only occur by incorporating health into upstream decision-making, such as social and economic policy (e.g., the “Health in All Policies” approach). [ 71] This study reinforces these points and criticisms coming from both sociologists and public health professionals, as the intersectionality of maternal education and child’s race/ethnicity revealed disparities not observed when examining them individually.
